caption: Table 1: Classification error rate (%) for the standard CIFAR10-to-CIFAR10C CTTA task. All results are evaluated with the largest corruption severity level 5 in an online fashion. C1 to C15 are 15 corruptions for the datasets (see Sec. 5.1). CIFAR100C and ImagenetC use the same setup.
description: This table presents the classification error rates (%) achieved by different continual test-time adaptation (CTTA) methods on the CIFAR-10 to CIFAR-10C task.  The evaluation uses the highest corruption level (5) and is performed online.  Each column represents a different type of image corruption (C1-C15), and the average error rate across all corruption types is also shown.  The table includes several state-of-the-art CTTA methods for comparison, highlighting the performance of the proposed VCoTTA method.

caption: Table 1: Classification error rate (%) for the standard CIFAR10-to-CIFAR10C CTTA task. All results are evaluated with the largest corruption severity level 5 in an online fashion. C1 to C15 are 15 corruptions for the datasets (see Sec. 5.1). CIFAR100C and ImagenetC use the same setup.
description: This table presents the classification error rates for different continual test-time adaptation (CTTA) methods on the CIFAR-10 to CIFAR-10C task.  The error rates are shown for each of the 15 corruption types (C1-C15) at the highest severity level (level 5). The average error rate across all corruption types is also provided.  The table includes results for several baseline methods (Source, BN, Tent, COTTA, ROTTA, PETAL, SATA, DSS, SWA) and the proposed VCOTTA method.  CIFAR-100C and ImageNetC results use the same experimental setup.

caption: Table 1: Classification error rate (%) for the standard CIFAR10-to-CIFAR10C CTTA task. All results are evaluated with the largest corruption severity level 5 in an online fashion. C1 to C15 are 15 corruptions for the datasets (see Sec. 5.1). CIFAR100C and ImagenetC use the same setup.
description: This table presents the classification error rates (%) achieved by various continual test-time adaptation (CTTA) methods on the CIFAR-10 to CIFAR-10C task.  The results are averaged across 15 different types of image corruptions, each applied at the highest (level 5) severity. The table also shows a comparison with other CTTA methods and the baseline of using only the source data.  The same experimental setup was used for CIFAR-100C and ImageNet-C datasets.

caption: Table 2: Classification error rate (%) for the standard CIFAR100-to-CIFAR100C CTTA task.
description: This table presents the classification error rates achieved by various methods on the CIFAR100-to-CIFAR100C Continual Test-Time Adaptation (CTTA) task.  The error rates are calculated for each of the 15 different corruption types (C1-C15) applied to the CIFAR-100C dataset at the highest severity level (level 5). The 'Source' row shows the baseline error rate of the model before any adaptation, and the other rows present the results from different adaptation methods.  'Avg' represents the average error rate across all 15 corruption types.

caption: Table 3: Classification error rate (%) for the standard ImageNet-to-ImageNetC CTTA task.
description: This table presents the classification error rates achieved by various methods on the ImageNet-to-ImageNetC Continual Test-Time Adaptation (CTTA) task.  Each column represents a different type of image corruption (C1-C15), and the 'Avg' column shows the average error rate across all corruption types.  The results are presented for the largest corruption severity level (5). The methods compared include a baseline (Source), methods that only update Batch Normalization (BN), entropy-based methods (Tent), mean-teacher-based approaches (CoTTA, ROTTA), uncertainty-aware methods (PETAL, DSS, SWA), and the proposed VCOTTA method. The table allows a direct comparison of the effectiveness of these different approaches in handling image corruption during continual test-time adaptation.

caption: Table 4: Ablation study on under severity 5.
description: This ablation study evaluates the individual contributions of two components: Variational Warm-Up (VWU) and Symmetric Cross-Entropy (SCE).  It shows the impact on classification error rates for CIFAR10C, CIFAR100C, and ImageNetC datasets when either or both components are removed from the VCOTTA model.

caption: Table 6: Uncertainty estimation via NLL and BS.
description: This table presents the results of uncertainty estimation using negative log-likelihood (NLL) and Brier Score (BS) for different methods on CIFAR10C, CIFAR100C, and ImageNetC datasets.  Lower values indicate better uncertainty estimation.  The results are evaluated at the highest corruption severity level (5).

caption: Table 8: Analysis on confidence margin.
description: This table presents the ablation study on the confidence margin (epsilon) used in the entropy term of the proposed VCOTTA method.  It shows how different values of epsilon affect the performance across three datasets (CIFAR10C, CIFAR100C, and ImageNetC) at severity level 5.  The results indicate that the optimal epsilon value can vary depending on the dataset.

caption: Table 9: Different number of augmentation.
description: This table shows the effect of varying the number of augmentations used in the algorithm on the classification error rate. The results indicate that increasing the number of augmentations improves performance up to a certain point (32 in this case), after which further increases do not significantly impact the results.  The table compares the performance of CoTTA, PETAL, and VCOTTA across different augmentation numbers.

caption: Table 10: Error comparison between varional warm-up on CNN and directly pretraining BNN.
description: This table compares the classification error rates achieved by three different methods of obtaining pre-trained Bayesian Neural Network (BNN) models for continual test-time adaptation (CTTA). The first method involves directly training a BNN from scratch using variational inference (VI). The second method converts a pre-trained Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) to a BNN without using the variational warm-up strategy. The third method, proposed by the authors, converts a pre-trained CNN to a BNN using the variational warm-up strategy.  The results are presented for three datasets: CIFAR10C, CIFAR100C, and ImageNetC, demonstrating that the authors' proposed method using variational warm-up yields lower error rates.
section: F.1 Warm-up on CNN vs. Directly Pretraining BNN

caption: Table 11: Comparisons over 10 orders (avg ± std).
description: This table presents a comparison of the average performance (± standard deviation) of different continual test-time adaptation (CTTA) methods across 10 different corruption orders.  The methods are evaluated on three datasets (CIFAR10C, CIFAR100C, and ImageNetC) with a corruption severity level of 5. The results demonstrate the robustness and effectiveness of different methods in handling various corruption sequences.

caption: Table 1: Classification error rate (%) for the standard CIFAR10-to-CIFAR10C CTTA task. All results are evaluated with the largest corruption severity level 5 in an online fashion. C1 to C15 are 15 corruptions for the datasets (see Sec. 5.1). CIFAR100C and ImagenetC use the same setup.
description: This table presents the classification error rates of different continual test-time adaptation (CTTA) methods on the CIFAR-10 to CIFAR-10C task.  The error rates are shown for 15 different corruption types (C1-C15) at the highest severity level (level 5). The table compares various methods, including baselines (Source, BN), previous CTTA methods (Tent, COTTA, ROTTA, PETAL, SATA, DSS, SWA), and the proposed VCoTTA.  The average error rate across all corruption types is also provided for each method.  Similar experiments on CIFAR-100C and ImageNet-C datasets are conducted with the same setup.

caption: Table 13: Time and memory cost comparisons.
description: This table presents the memory usage (in GB) and the time cost (in seconds) per corruption for three different continual test-time adaptation (CTTA) methods: CoTTA, PETAL, and VCoTTA.  It allows for a comparison of the computational efficiency of these approaches.
